title: Welcome to my music blog
text:
After my motivation to post over at my regular blog hasn’t been great recently, I thought I could start a blog on something that occupies more of my time now: music. I won’t forget coding and all that, not least because this blog is written in quarto, and rendered and published using GitHub actions (if you don’t know what those are, never mind. If you do, you might be interested in my original blog too).
I will tell you here about music I listen to, music and musicians that inspire me, and maybe one day also music that I make. I might also geek out on music hardware, especially about looping. Are you ready?

title: Waving your hands to create music - say hello to the theremin
text:
I have become a regular listener of the BBC’s Add to playlist podcast (which definitely deserves its own blog post, but that’s something for another day). It’s a programme where I am exposed to a lot of music I haven’t heard before, and the one experience I’d like to share with you today is hearing a theremin.
If you don’t know what that is - don’t fret, I didn’t know either. The Wikipedia article as usual has you covered: the theremin is an electronic instrument that looks like two antennae, which are actually half of a capacitor and act as position sensors for your hands. One hand controls the pitch and the other controls the amplitude of the sound. Caronlina Eyck has a nice video showing how she plays a scale:


It sounds quite eerily like a human voice, don’t you think? I also listened to the episode on the theremin by the Klassik für Klugscheisser Podcast (in German), which has a few more tidbits about the sounds and history of this instrument.
Anyway, the song I heard in the original podcast was an arrangement of Claire de Lune by Carolina Eyck for theremin and voice:

<a href="https://carolinaeyck.bandcamp.com/album/thetis-2086">Thetis 2086 by Carolina Eyck</a>

If you got hooked, here’s the whole album and here is her website.

title: Tiny desk concerts
text: Not much is needed for an exceptional musical experience - a tiny desk behind which musicians can play and an audience is all that is required with NPR’s Tiny Desk concert series. Luckily for us, we can watch online even if we do not make it to the studio. While I haven’t listened to nearly enough of them, I already have quite a few favouriters, which I’d like to share with you:

title: Tiny desk concerts
text:
Goat Rodeo
The Goat Rodeo Sessions is an album by/with Edgar Meyer, Chris Thile, Stuart Duncan, and Yo-Yo Ma. Classically inclined people will recognise at least Ma’s name, and yes, some classically-trained virtuosity is an aspect that can be heard, but there is so much more:

title: Tiny desk concerts
text:
Gaelynn Lea
As a violin player myself, I know many of the sounds that a violin can create. I learnt a whole lot of new ones with this video, though. Gaelynn Lea’s playing won the Tiny Desk contest of that year, and it really is something special:

title: Tiny desk concerts
text:
Imogen Heap and fancy technology
I’m starting to learn about all the fun stuff you can do with music when it is digital. Nevertheless, having something physical in your hands still has an appeasl - Imogen Heap combines both with super-fancy gloves, which allow her to control digital effects with gestures:


Is that enough inspiration for today?

title: Getting into looping - Zoë Keating
text:
Playing in orchestras and ensembles has always been fun - but coming back to music a bit more after a more sporty phase, I wasn’t quite attracted by classical ensembles. Then, with the help of some friends, I discovered looping, where you play and record yourself, so you can build up a whole ensemble on your own. I was fascinated, and this piece by Zoë Keating finally convinced me that I needed to get a looper:

<a href="https://music.zoekeating.com/album/one-cello-x-16-ep">One Cello x 16 (EP) by Zoe Keating</a>

If you are impatient, fast-forward to 2:10, I think it gets really fun from 2:20 or so. The cello is also very cool for looping because it is low enough to have a base, but flexible enough to play higher melodies and all sorts of different sounds. Another exmple where we can see Zoë play:


While Zoë uses a laptop and a midi controller, and programs her sequences herself, I decided I didn’t want to stare at a screen yet again, so I bought myself a pedal looper, and thereby started my looping adventure.

Zoë Keating: website, her albums on bandcamp
